On Sunday, May 4, 2003, at 18:13 US/Eastern, javainsel wrote:
>
> Whats the name of the measure which covers everything which must be
> tested, if one wants to test everything.
>
> I mean if bugless tests are written to the that perfect measure and
> all test execute green, then there is no bug in the tested code I
> think.
>
> Is such a perfect measure existing?

No, there is no such measure and there can be no general proof for the 
correctness of programs. Read Goedel.

The bottom line is that such a metric would have to measure every 
single possible path through all legal programs. In order to do that, 
the measuring program would need to know whether the algorithms in the 
programs every terminate--- something which Goedel proved is impossible 
in the general case.

Coverage analysis can get close if several metrics are used in 
combination. Brian Marrick goes through this in detail in The Craft of 
Software Testing. But even if a perfect metric were possible, as 
another poster pointed out, a coverage metric will not tell you if a 
particular line, expression, or branch is necessary at all or fits into 
the system as a whole. Test-first does a much better job of eliminating 
unnecessary coverage by eliminating unnecessary code.

Use coverage analysis as a tool to gain insight about what your code 
and tests are doing. Use your wits to determine what tests to add (or 
code to remove). Train your wits by gaining experience and reading good 
books. Nothing will do the job for you.
